docs.lead_paragraph: THE quarrel gets played out daily in thousands of families. Stay away from marijuana, the exasperated parent warns; it will mess up your future. The teen-ager retorts: But you tried it and it didn't hurt you. At home or school, when the conversation turns to illegal drugs the subject is usually marijuana. As many as 70 million Americans, including many of today's parents, have smoked it. And as their children can be quick to point out, the vast majority did not go on to be addicted to cocaine or heroin.

headline.main: Teen-agers and Marijuana; Scaring Them Straight Has Lost Its Edge

docs.abstract: Advocates of legalizing marijuana agree with prohibitionists that drug should not be used by teens, but they do not believe that marijuana is 'gateway' to use of hard drugs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE highly popular drug Prozac and its synthetic rivals may soon be in for competition in this country from a natural herb for the treatment of mild to moderately severe depression. The herb, St. John's wort, is already by far the favored therapy for depression in Germany, where it has been used therapeutically for centuries. In 1994, about 66 million daily doses of St. John's wort were prescribed by German doctors, who turn to other drugs only when the herbal remedy fails to work.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on pros and cons of St John's wort, an herb, as a treatment for mild to moderately severe depression; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is a lush green plant with bright yellow flowers and a homely name: St. John's wort in English and Johanniskraut in German. For centuries people in many countries used it to heal wounds and it found wide use in Germany as a tea that could soothe nerves and relieve melancholy.

headline.main: In Germany, Humble Herb Is a Rival to Prozac

docs.abstract: New clinical studies show that St John's wort, ancient herbal remedy, provides measurable relief to people with mild and moderate depression without side effects of drugs like Prozac, which currently dominates roughly $6 billion worldwide market for antidepressants; pharmacologists caution that there are still important gaps in knowledge about herb; there have yet to be any long-term clinical studies, so there is no information on herb's effectiveness as 'maintenance' treatment; drawing of St John's wort; photos (L)
